comments.raw_text:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:8.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/8.0
Build ID: 20111104165243

Steps to reproduce:

- set gfx.color_management.enablev4 = true
- went to a webpage containing PNGs, e.g., logo in upper left corner of http://www.openstreetmap.org/


Actual results:

- PNG images are rendered with a blue cast, as shown in attachement (JPEGs are fine)


Expected results:

- PNG images should have normal colors
comments.creator: hopet@ics.muni.cz
comments.text:
Created attachment 575876
Screenshot of the problem.

comments.raw_text: Works for me. Could you make sure that you do not install a bogus Color Profile?
comments.author: VYV03354@nifty.ne.jp
comments.text: Works for me. Could you make sure that you do not install a bogus Color Profile?
comments.creator: VYV03354@nifty.ne.jp

comments.text: The color profile I use is created by Monaco Optix calibration probe and accompanying software. It's a 3D profile with color compression turned off. The profile works fine both with Windows and other apps (including Adobe Creative Suite 5.5). I've attached it to this report.
comments.author: hopet@ics.muni.cz
comments.creator: hopet@ics.muni.cz

comments.author: b56girard@gmail.com
comments.text:
Took a quick look with ColorSync, the profile has an invalid 'Mdat' so it isn't strictly valid.

Opening the profile in safari shows faded colors in the following page but not in firefox:
http://www.color.org/version4html.xalter
comments.creator: b56girard@gmail.com
comments.raw_text:
Took a quick look with ColorSync, the profile has an invalid 'Mdat' so it isn't strictly valid.

Opening the profile in safari shows faded colors in the following page but not in firefox:
http://www.color.org/version4html.xalter

Is the Mdap field responsible for this effect? And is there any way to correct it?

Other applications interpret the profile just fine, so it makes me wonder if this is so critical to create as ugly artifacts as I see with PNG in Firefox. Also, JPEGs behave correctly, it's a problem only with PNGs (and yes, this is the reason why http://www.color.org/version4html.xalter looks OK - it uses JPEGs; and this why I gave the link to the OSM logo).
comments.text:
Is the Mdap field responsible for this effect? And is there any way to correct it?

Other applications interpret the profile just fine, so it makes me wonder if this is so critical to create as ugly artifacts as I see with PNG in Firefox. Also, JPEGs behave correctly, it's a problem only with PNGs (and yes, this is the reason why http://www.color.org/version4html.xalter looks OK - it uses JPEGs; and this why I gave the link to the OSM logo).
comments.author: hopet@ics.muni.cz
comments.creator: hopet@ics.muni.cz

comments.text: Btw, I've find out that it is really a problem with the profile - if I create and use a normal (not 3D-LUT) profile, firefox works correctly. The normal profile is now attached as well, so that you can compare both. But having the 3D profile is rather preferable for me as it provides more accurate color rendering based on colorimeter measurements.
comments.author: hopet@ics.muni.cz
comments.creator: hopet@ics.muni.cz
